case_name: State of Andhra v. Sub-Inspector of Police

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 626 of 1961 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 626 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 922 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 18, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 922 of 1956.

facts.text: Deputy Inspector General of Police, State of Andhra, passed an order dismissing the respondent who was a sub-inspector of police appointed on probation from service on March 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On March 10, 1955, the Deputy Inspector General of Police, State of Andhra, passed an order dismissing the respondent  who was a sub-inspector of police appointed on probation  from service.

facts.text: On appeal to the Inspector General of Police, the dismissal order was altered into one of removal from service dated September 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Inspector General of Police, the order was altered into one of removal from service. The respondent then. moved the High Court of Andhra pradesh by a petition under Art. 226

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 in Andhra Pradesh High Court for writ of certiorari quashing the orders dated September 24, 1955 and March 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then. moved the High Court of Andhra pradesh by a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of certiorari or other appropriate writ or direction quashing the proceedings

facts.text: High Court quashed the two impugned orders.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court quashed the two impugned orders. Against the order passed by the High Court, this appeal is preferred with special leave.

facts.text: Respondent was in charge of the police station Kodur, Visakhapatnam District at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to set out in some detail the facts which gave rise to the departmental proceedings against the respondent resulting in his removal from service. The respondent was at the material time

facts.text: On February 18, 1954, an offence of house-breaking and theft was reported at the police station and registered on February 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was at the material time in charge of the police station Kodur, Visakhapatnam District. On February 18, 1954, an offence of house-breaking and theft was reported at the police station

facts.text: Durgalu was suspected offender in the report of Village Munsif of Vechalam.

anchor.surface_text: and was registered on February 19,1954. It was recited in the report of the Village Munsif of Vechalam that one Durgalu who was then absconding was suspected to be-the offender.

facts.text: Durgalu was apprehended by the Village Munsif of Kalogotla on March 5, 1954, and handed over to Village Munsif of Vechalam.

anchor.surface_text: This Durgalu was apprehended by the Village Munsif of Kalogotla on March 5, 1954, and was handed over to the Village Munsif of Vechalam, who in his turn sent Durgalu to Kodur police station

facts.text: Village Munsif of Vechalam sent Durgalu to Kodur police station with village servants V. Polayya, Vechalapu Simhachalam, Kodamanchali Simhachalam and Koduru Sumudram.

anchor.surface_text: who in his turn sent Durgalu to Kodur police station with village servants V. Polayya, Vechalapu Simhachalam, Kodamanchali Simhachalam and Koduru Sumudram.

facts.text: State case: Durgalu handed over to respondent on night of March 5, 1954, but no written acknowledgment given, no entry in station diary, confined without magistrate order.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of the State that Durgalu was handed over to the respondent on the night of March 5, 1954, but numberwritten acknowledgment in token of having received Durgalu from the village servants

facts.text: On March 7, 1954, respondent entrusted charge of police station to head constable and left for Kakinada on casual leave for five days, returned March 12, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On March 7, 1954, the respondent entrusted charge of the police station to a head companystable and left for Kakinada on casual leave for five days. He returned to Kodur on March 12, 1954.

facts.text: After respondent's departure, constables arrested Reddy Simhachalam and brought to police station evening of March 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: After the departure of the respondent, some companystables arrested one Reddy Simhachalam and brought him to the police station in the evening of March 7, 1954.

facts.text: State case: Reddy Simhachalam tortured by police constables Nos. 1199, 363 and 662, became unconscious.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of the State that as a result of torture by police companystables Nos. 1199, 363 and 662, Reddy Simhachalam became unconscious.

facts.text: Dead body of Reddy Simhachalam found floating in well near police station morning of March 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The dead body of Reddy Simhachalam was found floating in a well near the police station on the morning of March 9, 1954, and an enquiry into the circumstances

facts.text: Revenue Divisional Officer, Narsipatnam commenced enquiry into death.

anchor.surface_text: in which the death took place was companymenced by the Revenue Divisional Officer, Narsipatnam. In the enquiry, Durgalu made a statement that he had witnessed

facts.text: Durgalu stated in RDO enquiry that he witnessed torture of Reddy Simhachalam by three constables.

anchor.surface_text: In the enquiry, Durgalu made a statement that he had witnessed the torture of Reddy Simhachalam, in the police station, by the three companystables.

facts.text: Police constables Nos. 1199, 363, 662 charged before Sub-Magistrate Chodavaram under ss. 304, 201 r/w 114 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Police companystables Nos. 1199, 363 and 662 were then charged before the Sub- Magistrate, Chodavaram, for offences under ss. 304 2  and 201 read with s. 114 I.P. Code,

facts.text: Durgalu retracted statement before Sub-Magistrate, said untrue and induced by police, escaped from village servants before reaching Kodur PS on March 5, 1954, re-arrested March 8, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Sub- Magistrate, Durgalu retracted his earlier statement and stated that the statement that he was an eye-witness to the torture of Reddy Simhachalam was untrue

facts.text: Sub-Magistrate discharged the police constables holding no prima facie case once Durgalu turned hostile.

anchor.surface_text: and that he was induced to make that statement by the police. He deposed that he had escaped from the custody of the village servants before he reached the police-station Kodur

facts.text: Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam suo motu called record, held proved Durgalu arrested March 5, taken to Kodur PS, wrongfully confined since then, rejected escape story.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub- Magistrate discharged the police companystables holding that once Durgalu the only eye-witness turned hostile, there was numberdirect evidence on which even a prima facie case

facts.text: Departmental enquiry commenced in May 1954 against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: A departmental enquiry was companymenced in May 1954 against the respondent.

facts.text: Charge against respondent: Reprehensible conduct in wrongfully confining Durgalu from night of 5-3-54 to 7-3-1954 in police station.

anchor.surface_text: The charge in the disciplinary proceedings against the respondent after it was amended ran as follows -- Reprehensible companyduct in wrongfully companyfining a K.D, Chandana Durgalu accused

facts.text: Respondent's explanation: Durgalu not handed over on March 5, 1954, before leave on March 7.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted an explanation in which he submitted that Durgalu was number handed over to him on March S, 1954, as alleged number at any time before he proceeded

facts.text: Deputy Superintendent of Police held enquiry, report on October 27, 1954, found strong case against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Superintendent of Police held the departmental enquiry and submitted his report on October 27, 1954, setting out the evidence of the witnesses examined

facts.text: No dispute that Durgalu arrested March 5, 1954 and sent by VM Vechalam to Kodur PS.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that Durgalu was arrested on March 5, 1954, and was sent by the Village Munsif, Vechalam with his report to the police station Kodur.

facts.text: Disputed question: whether Durgalu handed over to respondent on night of March 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The only question in dispute was whether Durgalu was handed over to the respondent on March 5, 1954, as stated by the witnesses for the State.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on April 10, 1963, allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, dismissed writ petition.

issues.text: Whether the High Court under Article 226 of the Constitution is a court of appeal over departmental enquiry findings and can re-appreciate evidence to arrive at an independent finding, or can only interfere where there is no competent authority, procedure violated, natural justice breached, no evidence, or wholly arbitrary conclusion?

anchor.surface_text: in a proceeding under Art. 226 of the Constitution are accepted by the High Court but that general rule does not apply whenever an important principle of jurisprudence is discarded in reaching such findings, and since the fundamental rule that a person should be punished only after the entire evidence in the case had been considered and he is found liable beyond reasonable doubt, had not been followed, the conclusions of the departmental authorities were vitiated. The High Court again observed that the orders passed by the departmental authorities were vitiated because of two other matters (i) that the Enquiry Officer declined to summon and examine two witnesses for the defence even though a request in that behalf was made and (ii) that there was no charge against the respondent of falsifying the record by omitting to write what he had done or what happened in the police station, and he had not been given an opportunity of meeting such a charge and therefore the respondent had no fair hearing consistent with the principles of natural justice.

issues.text: Whether in departmental proceedings the charge must be proved beyond reasonable doubt as in criminal trials, and failure to do so vitiates the findings allowing High Court interference under Article 226?

anchor.surface_text: they failed to appreciate the full significance of the rule concerning the onus of proving. The rule meant that everything essential to the establishment of a charge lies on the person, who seeks to establish the charge. It further means that the two sets of evidence in the case must not be examined separately in order to ascertain first whether those for establishing the charge have proved it and then to examine the defence in order to see how far the conclusions are unjustified. The better approach, which has been described as the golden thread in the web of criminal law is to examine the whole evidence in order to ascertain how far the liability of the person proceeded against has been established beyond reasonable doubt. The High Court then observed that ordinarily the conclusions on questions of fact by a body or tribunal in a proceeding under Art. 226 of the Constitution are accepted by the High Court but that general rule does not apply whenever an important principle

issues.text: Whether principles of natural justice were violated because the Enquiry Officer refused to summon and examine two requested defence witnesses?

Whether principles of natural justice were violated because there was no explicit charge of falsifying records by omitting to enter receipt of Durgalu, depriving the respondent of opportunity to meet it?
Whether there was some evidence before the departmental authorities reasonably supporting the conclusion that Durgalu was handed over to the respondent on March 5, 1954?

anchor.surface_text: rules of natural justice are not violated. Where there is some evidence, which the authority entrusted with the duty to hold the enquiry has accepted and which evidence may reasonably support the conclusion that the delinquent Officer is guilty of the charge, it is not the function of the High Court in a petition for a writ under Art. 226 to review the evidence and to arrive at an independent finding on the evidence. The High Court may undoubtedly interfere where the departmental authorities have held the proceedings against the delinquent in a manner inconsistent with the rules of natural justice or in violation of the statutory rules prescribing the mode of enquiry or where the authorities have disabled themselves from reaching a fair decision by some considerations extraneous to the evidence and the merits of the case or by allowing themselves to be influenced by irrelevant considerations or where the conclusion on the very face of it is so wholly arbitrary and capricious that no reasonable person could ever have arrived at that conclusion,

holdings.text: The High Court is not constituted in a proceeding under Art. 226 of the Constitution a Court of appeal over the decision of the authorities holding a departmental enquiry against a public servant. It is concerned to determine whether the enquiry is held by an authority competent in that behalf, and according to the procedure prescribed in that behalf, and whether the rules of natural justice are not violated.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is number companystituted in a proceeding under Art. 226 of the Constitution a Court of appeal over the decision of the authorities holding a departmental enquiry against a public servant iris companycerned to determine whether the enquiry is held by an authority companypetent in that behalf,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reviews legality of process, not re-appreciates facts; interferes only on jurisdictional errors, procedural flaws, natural justice violations, no evidence, or arbitrariness.

holdings.text: Where there is some evidence, which the authority entrusted with the duty to hold the enquiry has accepted and which evidence may reasonably support the conclusion that the delinquent Officer is guilty of the charge, it is not the function of the High Court in a petition for a writ under Art. 226 to review the evidence and to arrive at an independent finding on the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Where there is some evidence, which the authority entrusted with the duty to hold the enquiry has accepted and which evidence may reasonably support the companyclusion that the delinquent Officer is guilty of the charge, it is number the function of the High Court in a petition for a writ under Art. 226 to review the evidence and to arrive at an independent finding on the evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Departmental authorities are sole judges of facts if supported by some legal evidence; adequacy/reliability not for High Court review.

holdings.text: There is no warrant for the view expressed by the High Court that in considering whether a public officer is guilty of the misconduct charged against him, the rule followed in criminal trials that an offence is not established unless proved by evidence beyond reasonable doubt to the satisfaction of the Court, must be applied.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberwarrant for the view expressed by the High Court that in companysidering whether a public officer is guilty of the misconduct charged against him, the rule followed in criminal trials that an offence is number established unless proved by evidence beyond reasonable doubt to the satisfaction of the Court, must be applied,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Departmental proceedings distinct from criminal trials; proof beyond reasonable doubt not required.

holdings.text: The respondent did not, after the examination of police constable No. 506, desire to examine the two police constables Nos. 178 and 569, whom he originally wanted to examine; no violation of natural justice in refusing to summon them.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent desired to examine police companystables Nos. 178, 506 and 569 to prove that Durgalu was number in the lock-up till March 8, 1954. Police companystable No. 506 was examined as a witness for the respondent, and the Enquiry Officer has number accepted his evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent promised to produce witnesses himself, examined one, signed proceedings acknowledging completion, no timely objection raised.

holdings.text: The charge and the statement of facts form part of a single document on the basis of which proceedings were started against the respondent and it would be hypercritical to proceed on the view that though the respondent was expressly told in the statement of facts which formed part of the charge-sheet, that he had failed to record that Durgalu was handed over to him, that ground of reprehensible conduct was not included in the charge.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the respondent was that he had wrongfully companyfined Durgalu on March 5, 1954, to March 7, 1954, in the police station. In the statement of facts which accompanied the charge-sheet it was stated in express terms that the respondent had number recorded in any of the diaries of the police station that Durgalu was handed over to him on March 5, 1954.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement of facts appended to charge explicitly mentioned no entry made; no objection raised timely; full notice given.

holdings.text: The Enquiry Officer had accepted the evidence of witnesses for the State that Durgalu was handed over to the respondent on March 5, 1954, and there is some legal evidence on which findings can be based.

anchor.surface_text: The Enquiry Officer had accepted the evidence of witnesses for the Sate that Durgalu was handed over to the respondent on March 5, 1954, and the observation that the respondent may have the benefit of doubt if the judgment of the Magistrate is companysidered sacred truth appears to have been made in a somewhat sarcastic vein,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Village servants' testimony accepted by enquiry officer and appellate authorities reasonably supports conclusion of wrongful confinement.

holdings.text: In our Judgment the proceedings before the departmental authorities were regular and were not vitiated on account of any breach of the rules of natural justice. The conclusions of the departmental officers were fully borne out by the evidence before them and the High Court had no jurisdiction to set aside the order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had full numberice of the charge against him, and he examined witnesses in support of his defence and made several argumentative representations before the Deputy Inspector General, the Inspector General of Police and the Government of Andhra Pradesh. In our Judgment the proceedings before the departmental authorities were regular and were number vitiated on account of any breach of the rules of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full notice, opportunity to defend, witnesses examined, no procedural breaches; evidence supports findings.
